author: Deleted User
content: Anyone from OpenEthereum working on an EIP1559 implementation? I could write something up, pretty familiar with the codebases at this point

author: pintail_xyz
content: I'm currently writing an article about 1559, the origins of the idea and reasons for it. One of the things I wanted to include was a reference to some of the historical research that was done looking at the opportunity cost for miners to include transactions, since their chances of successfully mining the next block are reduced by transaction processing overhead. But I can't seem to find a reference - anyone know one?

author: richguy81
content: /giphy 1

author: barnabemonnot
content: on the tradeoff between block size and orphaning, this paper is quite good: https://www.bitcoinunlimited.info/resources/feemarket.pdf

author: pintail_xyz
content: thanks

author: pintail_xyz
content: I do remember someone ran the numbers for ethereum too though, don't suppose you remember?

author: barnabemonnot
content: i think it was <@!273808422753796097> here: https://blog.ethereum.org/2016/10/31/uncle-rate-transaction-fee-analysis/

author: barnabemonnot
content: oh yeah and he cites this other paper which is quite well-known: https://www.gsd.inesc-id.pt/~ler/docencia/rcs1314/papers/P2P2013_041.pdf

author: pintail_xyz
content: thanks

author: claberus
content:
> Anyone from OpenEthereum working on an EIP1559 implementation? I could write something up, pretty familiar with the codebases at this point
<@456226577798135808> We still don't have resources to work on this, it would be good to have your help!

author: pintail_xyz
content: <@486501030046203915> I noticed in the repo you'd done some work looking at the Escalator proposal as well as 1559. Is the intention to look at some sort of 1559-Escalator hybrid, or just to compare Escalator and 1559 separately?

author: sky.cactus
content: They both are useful EIPs, and if they both land then they touch the same parts of code.

author: sky.cactus
content: If EIP-2718 makes it in (ü§û) that should make it significantly easier to integrate both of them.

author: pintail_xyz
content: Ah cool. To be honest I was pretty amazed to see Escalator appear in response to 1559 - it looks pretty elegant to me and although it doesn't offer quite the same benefits as 1559, it still looks like a big UX improvement.

author: pintail_xyz
content: So if both were implemented, is the idea that Escalator would be able to increase the tip/bribe, or only the fee_cap?

author: sky.cactus
content: Bribe I believe is the most popular choice.

author: sky.cactus
content: With a limit at fee_cap.

author: pintail_xyz
content: makes sense

author: sky.cactus
content: Escalator is mildly annoying for clients when it comes to transaction sorting, which is unfortunate.  But I doubt it is annoying enough to block it.

author: sky.cactus
content: (you have to re-sort the transactions every second if you want to maximize gas income)

author: pintail_xyz
content: I guess the difference between second-by-second resorting and some sort of lower-resource heuristic might not be that great?

author: pintail_xyz
content: in terms of maximising income I mean

author: pintail_xyz
content: <@301186049323958275> I was planning to link to your article from mine, but how should I describe you. Are you currently working for the EF or another organisation?

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm best described as "random internet person with too many opinions".

author: sky.cactus
content: (not currently employed by EF or other organization)

author: pintail_xyz
content: (likewise) or at least this is a hobby. But luckily I don't have to introduce myself in my own article

author: barnabemonnot
content:
> <@486501030046203915> I noticed in the repo you'd done some work looking at the Escalator proposal as well as 1559. Is the intention to look at some sort of 1559-Escalator hybrid, or just to compare Escalator and 1559 separately?
<@466048602326695938>  intention was more to compare with the hybrid (the ‚Äúfloating escalator‚Äù here: https://github.com/ethereum/rig/blob/master/eip1559/combination.md) but yes it‚Äôs not fully implemented in the library yet

author: barnabemonnot
content: Although implementing it is not the hard part, it‚Äôs more finding out how users should set up their escalators in a meaningful sense, like what should be the parameters they choose
